descriptionSet.description: The picture shows a muscular wrestler with a thick mustache flexing his arms. He is wearing briefs and beside him lies a gada (Indian mace/club).

titleSet.title: "Gama Pahalwan World Champion"
گاما پہلوان ورلڈ چمپین; विश्व विजयी गामा पहलवान

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: S. S. L. Shyam Sunder Lal Agrawal Picture Publisher Chauk, Kanpur.
text-ur: گاما پہلوان ورلڈ چمپین
text-transcription-ur: Gama Pahalwan world champion
text-hi: विश्व विजयी गामा पहलवान
text-hi: श्यामसुन्दर लाल अग्रवाल चित्र प्रकाशक चौक,कानपुर
description-en: The picture shows a muscular wrestler with a thick mustache flexing his arms. He is wearing briefs and beside him lies a gada (Indian mace/club). (gs/ys/sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The man depicted is Gama Pahalwan, one of the most famous Indian wrestlers in the 20th century. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Indian wrestling developed within its own long and distinctive martial arts traditions—quite independently of western wrestling—with Hindu and Muslim variants celebrating, respectively, Hanuman and Ali. Most cities had akharas (gymnasia), communities in which boys and young men could learn wrestling and its strict disciplines: rigorous training regimes, high fat diets, religious ritual and celibacy (see Alter 1992). Wrestling was central to subaltern male performance cultures of early twentieth century India: its champions became folk heroes, celebrated with nationalist zeal. (Rosie Thomas) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Gama, ‘Lion of Punjab,’ was a legend even amongst wrestling heroes. Undefeated throughout his life, his daily diet included ten litres of milk, half a litre of ghee, a litre and a half of butter, and two kilograms of fruit. In 1910 in London, Gama and his brother, Imam Bakhsh, routed a succession of Europeans who, to that date, had considered themselves ‘champions;’ in 1928 Gama definitively defeated the European Zbyszko, the previous world champion, in forty-two seconds in front of forty thousand triumphant spectators in Patiala. After that, no one agreed to fight him again. Hamida, who fought as one of his proxies, was also part of this extraordinary Punjabi Muslim extended family, which provided nationalist role models to lower class men. (Rosie Thomas) (gs)
related literature: Alter, Joseph S. 1992. "The Wrestler’s Body: Identity and Ideology in North India". Berkeley, Oxford: University of California Press. (gs)
related literature: Muzumdar, S. 1942 "Strong men over the years. A chronicle of athletes".Lucknow: Oudh Printing Works. (gs)
related literature: Thomas, Rosie 2010. "Still Magic. An Aladdin's Cave of 1950s B-Movie Fantasy" (gs)
